Eric J. Bowman wrote:
> ... a resource
> is a set (though it may have only one member) ...

I think this is wrong.

A resource MAY or MAY NOT be a container. A container is a kind of  
resource that contains (aggregates) other resources:


--Apple-Mail-31--139693993
Content-Type: application/pdf;
	x-unix-mode=0666;
	name=pastedGraphic.pdf
Content-Disposition: inline;
	filename=pastedGraphic.pdf

[ Attachment content not displayed ]
--Apple-Mail-31--139693993
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=UTF-8;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed


It may impose an ordering on its components, or not.

The URL of a contain=
er may or may not terminate in a path delimiter,  
but its canonical form i=
ncludes a terminating path delimiter. The URL  
for a component of a contai=
ner resource is the URL of the container,  
plus some path delimiter, plus =
a path element uniquely identifying  
the component within the container. E=
.g.:

   http://fruit.org/apples/ (the container)
   http://fruit.org/apple=
s/goldendelicious-1 (a component)

I would argue that goldendelicious-1 is =
not a set of one apple, it is  
just an apple.

Is this contentious?
-- 
=
=E7=8A=AC Chris Burdess

   deserve neither liberty nor safety." - Benjamin Frank=
